questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of vaginal discharge and itching for 1 week. Upon examination, a profuse, thin, frothy yellow-green discharge and a strawberry cervix are noted. Which of the following statements regarding the causative organism is NOT true?

choices.text: Flagellated trophozoite is the infective form.
It has a characteristic twitching motility.
It has one anterior and 4 posterior flagella.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with a profuse, thin, frothy yellow-green discharge and a strawberry cervix, describes a case of Trichomoniasis, with 4 anterior flagella and 1 lateral flagellum (5 flagella).

 

Trichomoniasis:

  • It is the most common parasitic sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by a flagellated parasite, Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • It has only the trophozoite stage; there is no cyst stage.
  • Trophozoite has two forms:
    • Flagellated trophozoite: Infective and diagnostic form (Option A).
    • Amoeboid trophozoite: Actively replicating form (found in the tissue feeding stage).


 

Trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis

  • It is a pear-shaped organism.
  • It shows characteristic jerky or twitching motility in saline mount preparation (Option B).
  • It bears five flagella—four anterior flagella and one lateral flagellum called as recurrent flagellum.
  • It has a single nucleus containing a central karyosome (Option D).


 

Trophozoite

Feature

Trichomonas vaginalis

Giardia lamblia

Shape

Pear-shaped or ovoid

Heart-shaped or pyriform (tennis racket-shaped)

Size

10-30 µm in length, 5-10 µm in breadth

15 µm long, 9 µm wide, 4 µm thick

Flagella

Five flagella- Four anterior flagella and one along the undulating membrane

Four pairs of flagella arising from the blepharoplast

Axostyle

Prominent, runs the full length and projects posteriorly like a tail

One axostyle running along the midline

Cytoplasm

Contains prominent siderophilic granules along the axostyle and costa

It has two parabasal bodies

Movement

Rapid, jerky, or twitching motion

Slow oscillation resembling a "falling leaf" movement

Other Structures

Undulating membrane which reaches up to the middle of the body

Concave sucking disk on the ventral side for attachment to mucosa

Images

questions.text: A 42-year-old man from a rural area in Africa presents to the clinic with a two-week history of fever, headaches, and general malaise. He reports experiencing night sweats and often feels excessively tired during the day. On examination, there is notable posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings?
questions.solution:
Sleeping sickness is a parasitic disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Trypanosoma, transmitted to humans through the bite of infected tsetse flies. It primarily affects rural populations in sub-Saharan Africa.

Causative agents: There are two forms of sleeping sickness, each caused by different subspecies of Trypanosoma brucei:

  1. Trypanosoma brucei gambiense: Causes West African sleeping sickness and is responsible for the more chronic form of the disease.
  2. Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense: Causes East African sleeping sickness and typically leads to a more acute and severe form of the disease.

Transmission

  • Vector: Both forms are transmitted by tsetse flies (Glossina species), which bite humans to feed on their blood. The flies are typically found in rural areas near rivers and lakes.
  • Reservoir Hosts: T. brucei rhodesiense is often associated with wild and domestic animals serving as reservoir hosts, while T. brucei gambiense is primarily human-centric.

  • Clinical features: Symptoms may appear weeks to months after infection and include:

    • Early stage: Fever, Headaches, fatigue and Joint pain
    • Winterbottom sign- Swelling of lymph nodes (particularly posterior cervical lymph nodes in T. brucei gambiense).
    • Late stage: As the disease progresses, especially in T. brucei gambiense, symptoms may include -
    • Neurological involvement leads to confusion, personality changes, and sleep disturbances (insomnia or excessive daytime sleepiness)
    • Ataxia (loss of coordination)
    • Coma

In T. brucei rhodesiense, the disease can progress more rapidly, with severe symptoms developing in weeks.

Diagnosis

  • Serological Tests: Detection of antibodies against the parasites (e.g., ELISA).
  • Microscopy: Examination of blood, lymphatic fluid, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) for the presence of the parasites.
  • PCR

Treatment

  • Early Stage (no CNS involvement):
    • Pentamidine: Used for T. brucei gambiense.
    • Suramin: Used for T. brucei rhodesiense.
  • Late Stage (CNS involvement):
    • Eflornithine: Preferred for T. brucei gambiense, particularly if the patient cannot tolerate melarsoprol.
    • Melarsoprol: Used for late-stage T. brucei rhodesiense and can be toxic, leading to side effects like encephalopathy.

Leptospirosis (Option C): This can present with fever and systemic symptoms, but it usually does not cause significant cervical lymphadenopathy or distinctive sleep pattern changes.

 

Malaria (Option B): While malaria presents with fever and malaise, it typically involves symptoms such as chills and rigours, and does not usually lead to the sleep disturbances seen in sleeping sickness.

 

Dengue fever(Option D): This can cause fever and malaise but is less likely to produce the specific symptoms of sleep disturbances and lymphadenopathy described.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the marked structure in the image below?

choices.text: Present in organisms that live in the intestines
Contains nonnuclear DNA found in addition to the nucleus

questions.solution:
The given picture depicts a Kinetoplast.

The kinetoplast is nonnuclear DNA found in addition to the nucleus, seen in trypanosomes. The flagellum originates near the kinetoplast, and its point of origin is called the basal body. (Option A ruled out)

Characteristics

Kinetoplastida

Flagellates without Kinetoplast

Possess a kinetoplast

Yes

No

Flagella

Single flagellum

Multiple flagella

Examples
  • Trypanosomes
  • Leishmania
  • Giardia (Option C ruled out)
  • Trichomonas

Transmission

Transmitted by blood-sucking insects.

Causes systemic or local infections.

Live in the intestine. (Option B ruled out)

Called intestinal flagellates.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			1. Leishman Donovan bodies
			
			
			a)

			
			
		
		
			
			2. Dohle bodies
			
			
			b)

			
			
		
		
			
			3. Henderson Petersen bodies
			
			
			c)

			
			
		
		
			
			4. Cowdry Type A bodies
			
			
			d)
questions.solution:
Histopathological Bodies in Microbiology

Leishman Donovan (LD) bodies

  • Found in untreated leishmaniasis.
  • They are light blue, ellipsoid structures measuring 2-4 μm in length.
  • LD bodies have an eccentric nucleus and a smaller kinetosome at the opposite pole.
  • These bodies are located within large macrophages (also known as Wright's cells).

Dohle bodies

  • Light blue-grey, oval, basophilic staining inclusions were found in the cytoplasm of neutrophils in the peripheral smear.
  • Seen in bacterial infections like tuberculosis, diphtheria, and typhoid,
  • Indicate defective neutrophil production and maturation.

Hendersen Petersen bodies

  • Molluscum contagiosum, caused by a poxvirus, is characterised by the presence of large, ellipsoid intracytoplasmic inclusions in the stratum spinosum and corneum of infected skin known as Henderson-Peterson bodies.
  • They are made up of nuclear and cytoplasmic protein aggregates and mark the site of viral replication.

Councilman Bodies

  • Acidophilic inclusion bodies are found in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes in viral infections like hepatitis and yellow fever.
  • These bodies result from hepatocyte apoptosis and are associated with ballooning degeneration of liver cells.

Cowdry Type A bodies

  • Cowdry bodies are eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions made of nucleic acid and protein, seen in infections like herpes, yellow fever, polio, and adenovirus.
  • Type A (found in herpes and yellow fever) appears as droplet-like masses with clear halos and chromatin margination around the nucleus.
  • Type B (associated with polio and adenovirus) lacks nuclear changes.

Negri bodies

  • Negri bodies are eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in neurons, primarily in rabies infection.
  • They represent sites of viral replication and are considered a hallmark of rabies in histopathological examination.

Torres bodies

The intranuclear inclusion body seen in liver cells infected with the yellow fever virus is composed of host proteins.

questions.text:
Match the following

 


	
		
			
			1. Darting motility
			
			
			a) Listeria monocytogenes
			
		
		
			
			2. Swarming motility
			
			
			b) Trichomonas vaginalis
			
		
		
			
			3. Tumbling motility
			
			
			c) Proteus
			
		
		
			
			4. Jerky motility
			
			
			d) Vibrio
questions.solution:
MOTILITY

MICROORGANISM

Darting motility

Vibrio, Campylobacter

Swarming motility

Proteus

Tumbling motility

Listeria monocytogenes

Stately motility

Clostridia

Corkscrew motility

Treponema pallidum

Falling leaf motility

Giardia lamblia

Twitching motility

Eiknella corrodens

Jerky motility

Trichomonas vaginalis

Gliding motility

Mycoplasma

Lashing motility

Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1. Naegleria fowleri
			
			
			a) Flagella
			
		
		
			
			2.Trichomonas cruzi
			
			
			b) Cilia
			
		
		
			
			3. Plasmodium
			
			
			c) Pseudopodia
			
		
		
			
			4. Balantidium coli
			
			
			d) Non-motile
questions.solution:
Organs of Locomotion in Protozoans

Amoebae

  • Entamoeba histolytica
  • Naegleria fowleri
  • Acanthamoeba

Pseudopodia

Flagellates

  • Trypanosoma
  • Leishmania
  • Giardia
  • Trichomonas

Flagella

Apicomplexa (Sporozoans)

  • Cryptosporidium
  • Isospora
  • Sarcocystis
  • Toxoplasma
  • Plasmodium
  • Babesia

Non-motile

Ciliophora

  • Balantidium coli

Cilia

questions.text: A 28-year-old male returns to his rural village after spending time in a forested area known for sandfly infestations. He presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his forearm that has gradually increased in size over the past month, as shown in the image below. The ulcer has raised, indurated borders and a necrotic base. The patient has no fever or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous leishmaniasis is caused by Leishmania species transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. It typically presents as one or more painless ulcers with raised borders and a necrotic base, often referred to as "kala-azar ulcers." In this scenario, the patient's painless ulcer on the forearm aligns perfectly with the clinical presentation of cutaneous leishmaniasis.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis:

 

Most commonly caused by L.Tropica.

 

Mode of transmission:

  • The most common mode of infection is through the bite of sandflies.
  • Infection may be transmitted from man to man or animal to man by direct inoculation or amastigotes.

 

Incubation period: The incubation period varies from 2 to 8 months.

 

Pathology:

  • Amastigote forms are found in histiocytes and endothelial cells.
  • There is an inflammatory granulomatous reaction with infiltration of lymphocyte and plasma cells.
  • Early lesions are papular, followed by ulceration necrosis. Papules and ulcers are the main pathological lesions. They heal over months to years, leaving scars.

 

Clinical features:

 

L. tropica causes old-world cutaneous leishmaniasis.

 

Three distinct patterns of old-world CL have been recognised.

 

  1. The anthroponotic urban type :
  • Causing painless dry ulcerating lesions, leading to disfiguring scars. The most important vector is P. sergenti. - It is seen mainly in children in endemic areas and is called as oriental sore or Delhi boil.
  1. The zoonotic rural type :
  • Causes moist ulcers which are inflamed, often multiple, caused by L. major.
  • Lesions due to L. major heal more rapidly than L. tropica. P. papatasi is the most important vector.
  1. Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis:
  • The nonulcerative and often diffuse lesions caused by L. aethiopica

 

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Microscopy: Smear is made from the material obtained from the indurated edge of nodule or sore and stained by Giemsa or Leishman stain.
  • Amastigotes are found in large numbers inside the macrophages.
  • A definitive diagnosis is made by demonstrating amastigote in the smear collected from the lesion.
  • Culture: Promastigote forms can be isolated by culture of the aspirate material in NNN medium.
  • Montenegro skin test (MST)

 

Treatment:

  • The specific treatment of CL is the same as VL.
  • Antimony-resistant diffuse CL can be treated with pentamidine.
  • Topical treatment consists of a paste of 10% charcoal in sulfuric acid or liquid nitrogen.

Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis (Option B) :

  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis is a more severe form of leishmaniasis that usually follows cutaneous leishmaniasis.
  • L. braziliensis complex causes both mucocutaneous leishmaniasis (espundia) and "CL''.
  • It involves the nose, mouth and larynx.
  • The patient experiences a nodule at the site of the sand fly bite with symptoms consistent with oriental sore.
  • Subsequent mucocutaneous involvement leads to nodules inside the nose, perforation of the nasal septum, and enlargement of the nose and lips (espundia)
  • The absence of any mucosal involvement in this patient, along with the focus on skin ulcers, suggests that this is not the correct diagnosis.

Leishmaniasis Recidivans (Option C) :

  • Leishmaniasis recidivans is a type of lesion seen in persons with a high degree of cell-mediated immunity to the parasite.
  • The lesions are chronic with alternating periods of activity and healing, characterised by a central scar with peripheral activity.
  • The lesions resemble those of lupus or tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Parasites are very scanty in the lesions.
  • The Leishmanin test is strongly positive.
  • Chemotherapy is not very useful.
  • Better results follow the local application of heat.
  • However, in this case, the patient presents with an acute, new ulcer rather than a recurrence of a previous lesion, making this option less likely.

Tuberculous Ulcer (Option D): A tuberculous ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and usually presents as a chronic, painless ulcer, which may occur in patients with systemic tuberculosis. While it can present similarly to cutaneous leishmaniasis, the clinical history (recent travel to an endemic area and the appearance of the ulcer) strongly supports a diagnosis of cutaneous leishmaniasis rather than a tuberculous ulcer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, previously treated for visceral leishmaniasis six months ago, now presents with multiple erythematous, hypopigmented, slightly scaly papules and plaques on her face, neck, and arms. The lesions are painless, gradually increasing in number, and there are no associated systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer (A)Post-Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis.

PKDL is a condition that can occur after successful treatment of visceral leishmaniasis, characterized by the appearance of skin lesions, typically several months to years post-treatment. The lesions often present as hypopigmented macules, papules, or plaques, primarily on exposed areas of the body.

Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis is a non ulcerative lesion of the skin seen in India, Nepal, Bangladesh and Sudan.

The lesions are of three types:

  1. Depigmented or hypopigmented macules: These commonly appear on the face, the trunk and extremities and resemble tuberculoid leprosy.
  2. Erythematous patches: These are distributed on the face in a "butterfly distribution."
  3. Nodular lesion: Both of the earlier mentioned lesions may develop into painless yellowish-pink non-ulcerating granulomatous nodules.

Diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis:

  • The nodular lesions are biopsied, and amastigote forms are demonstrated in stained sections.
  • The biopsy material can be cultured, or animal inoculation can be done.
  • Immunodiagnosis has no role in the diagnosis of PKDL.

 

Treatment of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis:

  • Liposomal amphotericin-8 (AmBisome) 2.5 mg/ kg/ day for 20 days

or

  • sodium stibogluconate (SSG) 20 mg/ kg/day for 40- 60 days is given.

 

Leprosy (Option B) : Leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae, presents with skin lesions, peripheral nerve damage, and is characterized by numbness and weakness. Although some skin manifestations can resemble those of PKDL, the systemic symptoms and characteristic nerve involvement help differentiate it.

 

Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (Option C): Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with ulcerative lesions or nodules, typically following a sandfly bite. Unlike PKDL, these lesions do not usually appear months to years after visceral leishmaniasis treatment and are associated with the presence of Leishmania parasites in the skin.


Psoriasis (Option D): Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterised by red, scaly patches and is often itchy. While it can present with similar erythematous plaques, the patient's history of recent visceral leishmaniasis and the specific characteristics of her lesions (hypopigmented and non-itchy) make psoriasis an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a 2-week history of fever, abdominal distension, fatigue, and significant weight loss. A rapid diagnostic test using the rK39 dipstick comes back positive. What is the recommended first-line drug for treating this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Liposomal Amphotericin B, is the recommended first-line treatment for visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Treatment for Kala-azar:

Pentavalent antimonial compound: Two pentavalent antimonial preparations are available:

  • Sodium stibogluconate (100 mg of Sbv/mL) (SSG)
  • Meglumine antimoniate (85 mg of Sbv/mL).
  • Dosage: The daily dose is 20 mg/ kg by rapid intravenous (TV) infusion or intramuscular (IM) injection for 20- 30 days.

Amphotericin-B: It is currently used as a first-line drug in Bihar. ln other parts of the world, it is used when initial antimonial treatment fails.

  • Dosage: 0.75-1.0 mg/ kg on alternate days for a total of 15 infusions.
  • Note: Fever with chills is almost seen in all patients, using amphotericin-8 infusions.

Liposomal amphotericin-B (AmBisome): It has been developed and used extensively to treat VL in all parts of the world. It is the only drug approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the treatment of VL.

  • Dose being 3 mg/ kg daily.
  • By using liposomal amphotericin-B, higher doses can be given, improving the cure, without toxicity.
  • Current recommendation in India is 10 mg/ kg single dose.

Paromomycin: Paromomycin is an intramuscular aminoglycoside antibiotic with antileishmanial activity.

  • Dosage: It is given in a dose of 11 mg/ kg daily for 21 days.

Miltefosine: It is the first oral drug approved for the treatment of leishmaniasis.

  • Dosage: 50 mg daily for 28 days for patients weighing less than 25 kg, and twice daily for patients weighing more than 25 kg.

Prophylaxis:

  • Early detection and treatment of all cases.
  • Integrated insecticidal spraying to reduce sandfly population.
  • Destruction of animal reservoir host in cases or zoonotic kala-azar.

Regime of coadministered drug include:

  • AmBisome + Paromomycin
  • AmBisome + Miltefosine
  • Paromomycin + Miltefosine

10% Charcoal in Sulfuric Acid (Option B) is administered topically for Cutaneous leishmaniasis not for visceral leishmaniasis.

Glucocorticoids (Option C) : Glucocorticoids are not used to treat visceral leishmaniasis. They may be used in respiratory complications associated with cutaneous leishmaniasis.
Pentamidine (Option D) : Pentamidine is used for certain infections but is not a first-line treatment for visceral leishmaniasis. It can be used for antimony resistant diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female from Africa presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pallor, and generalised lymphadenopathy. Given her clinical features, there is a high suspicion of kala-azar. Which laboratory tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

 


	rk39 serological test
	Bone marrow aspirate
	Splenic aspirate
	Liver biopsy
questions.solution:
rk39 serological test, bone marrow aspirate and splenic aspirate are 3 important investigations done for the diagnosis of kala-azar.

 

Diagnosis of Kala-azar :

Depends upon direct and indirect evidences:

CFT: complement fixation test; CIEP: counter immunoelectrophoresis; DAT: direct agglutination test; DNA: deoxyribonucleic acid; ELISA: enzyme linked immunosorbent assay; ICT: immunochromatographic test; IFAT: indirect immunofluorescent antibody test; LD: Leishman-Donovan; NNN: Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle; PCR: polymerase chain reaction; rK39: recombinant kinesin 39

 

Microscopy

Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of kala-azar / VL

 

Materials collected:

Peripheral blood smear: Peripheral blood contains the amastigotes present inside circulating monocytes. It is best to examine buffy coat smear, Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night.

 

Blood smear test showing macrophages with amastigotes and extracellular Leishmania parasites (white arrows)

 

Bone marrow aspirate: Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Bone marrow samples can also be obtained by puncturing the Iliac crest.

 

Bone marrow aspirate showed Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies) in macrophages characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Fig. A and B).

Splenic aspirate (most sensitive): Splenic aspirates are richer in parasites and, therefore, are more valuable for diagnosis. Splenic aspiration is contraindicated in patients with prolonged prothrombin time or if platelet count is less than 40,000/mm³

Lymph node aspirate: It is not useful in the diagnosis of Indian kala-azar

Culture

Media: NNN (Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle).

Serodiagnosis
  1. Detection of antigen: ELISA and PCR
  2. Detection of antibody:
    • rk39 test: A specific rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) method for antibodies using a recombinant leishmanial antigen rk 39. The sensitivity of the test is 98% and specificity is 90%.
    • Complement fixation test
    • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT)
    • Counter immunoelectrophoresis (CIEP)
    • ELISA and DOT-ELISA
    • Direct agglutination test (DAT)

Non-specific serum tests
  1. Napier aldehyde test
  2. Chopra's antimony test

Skin test

  • Leishmanin skin test- Montenegro test: Delayed hypersensitivity test.
  • Positive result is indicated by induration and erythema of 5 mm or more after 48-72 hours.
  • Positive result indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasites. In active kala-azar, this test is negative and becomes positive usually 6-8 weeks after cure from the disease.

Image obtained after 48 hours after injection

Complete blood count
  • It shows normocytic normochromic anemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Leukocyte count reveals leukopenia.
  • The ratio of leukocyte to erythrocyte is greatly altered and may be about 1:200 to 1:100 (normal 1:750).
  • The serum shows hypergammaglobulinemia and a reversal of the albumin: globulin (A: G) ratio.
  • Liver function tests show mild elevations of liver enzymes.
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated.


Liver biopsy is not a safe procedure and carries a risk of haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male with a three-month history of fever, weight loss, fatigue, night sweats, and abdominal distention, along with splenomegaly, anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia, recently returned from rural India, where he was exposed to the vector given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of the vector is a sandfly. The patient has a persistent fever, significant weight loss, splenomegaly, anaemia, and leukopenia, and has a history of exposure in an endemic area with exposure to sandflies, making Kala Azar the most likely diagnosis, also known as Visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Clinical features of kala-azar:

  • Onset: Insidious.
  • The clinical illness begins with high-grade fever which may be remittent with twice daily spikes or intermittent or less commonly continuous.
  • Night sweats
  • Splenomegaly starts early and is progressive and massive. It is usually soft and nontender.
  • Hepatomegaly is moderate.
  • Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic areas except the Indian subcontinent.
  • Skin becomes dry, rough and darkly pigmented (hence, the name kala-azar).
  • The hair becomes thin and brittle.
  • Cachexia with marked anaemia, emaciation and weight loss is seen.
  • Hematological abnormalities: Anemia is most always present and is usually severe leukopenia , thrombocytopenia is associated with epistaxis, gum bleeding, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.
  • Ascites and edema may occur due to hypoalbuminemia.
  • Renal involvement is also common.
  • In the late stage of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, VL can present as an opportunistic infection. HIV coinfection rate is 5% in India and 20% in African countries.
  • Secondary infections such as herpes, measles, pneumonia, tuberculosis, and bacillary dysentery may occur.
  • Most untreated patients die in about two years due to some intercurrent disease such as dysentery, diarrhoea and tuberculosis.

        Child with visceral leishmaniasis with hepatosplenomegaly

 

Diseases caused by Sandflies:

  • Leishmania
  • Sandfly fever caused by the Toscano virus
  • Bunya virus causing ‘Three-day fever’

 

Malaria (Option A): While malaria can present with fever and splenomegaly, it typically has more intermittent fever patterns and does not usually cause significant weight loss or leukopenia to the extent described in this case.

Dengue Fever (Option B): Dengue often causes fever and can lead to thrombocytopenia; however, it typically presents with severe joint and muscle pain ("breakbone fever"), and significant splenomegaly is not common.

Tuberculosis (Option D) : While tuberculosis can cause fever, weight loss, and systemic symptoms, it usually presents with respiratory symptoms (cough, hemoptysis) and does not typically lead to splenomegaly or the blood findings seen in this case.

questions.text: What is the infective form of Leishmania donovani?
questions.solution:
Promastigote is the infective form of Leishmania donovani.

Life Cycle of Leishmania donovani

  1. Infection of the Vector:
    • A female sandfly (e.g., Phlebotomus, Lutzomyia) bites an infected mammal and ingests blood containing amastigotes.
  2. Development in the Sandfly:
    • Inside the sandfly’s midgut, amastigotes transform into promastigotes, which multiply and migrate to the proboscis.
  3. Transmission to the Mammalian Host:
    • When the sandfly bites a new host, it injects the infective promastigotes.
  4. Transformation in the Host:
    • Promastigotes are engulfed by macrophages and transform into amastigotes, which are non-flagellated and replicate intracellularly.
  5. Replication and Dissemination:
    • Amastigotes multiply within macrophages, causing cell lysis and releasing new amastigotes to infect other macrophages.
  6. Transmission Back to the Sandfly:
    • If an uninfected sandfly bites the infected host, it ingests amastigotes, and the cycle continues.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the forms of Trypanosoma brucei that can be found in the blood of an infected individual?

choices.text: The trypomastigote form is the only stage present in the blood.
The epimastigote form is commonly found in human blood during acute infection.
The procyclic form is typically present in the bloodstream of infected humans.
Both the trypomastigote and epimastigote forms can be found in human blood.

questions.solution:
• Trypomastigote Form: This is the infective form of Trypanosoma brucei found in the bloodstream of infected humans. It is elongated and flagellated.
  • Epimastigote form: This form is primarily found in the tsetse fly (not present in human blood).
  • Procyclic form: This form occurs in the tsetse fly’s midgut (not found in the human bloodstream).

Diagnosis

  • Serological Tests: Detection of antibodies against the parasites (e.g., ELISA).
  • Microscopy: Examination of blood, lymphatic fluid, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) for the presence of the parasites.
  • PCR

Treatment

  • Early Stage (no CNS involvement):
    • Pentamidine: Used for T. brucei gambiense.
    • Suramin: Used for T. brucei rhodesiense.
  • Late Stage (CNS involvement):
    • Eflornithine: Preferred for T. brucei gambiense (if the patient cannot tolerate melarsoprol).
    • Melarsoprol: Used for late-stage T. brucei rhodesiense and can be toxic, leading to side effects like encephalopathy.
 

West African Trypanosomiasis

East African Trypanosomiasis

Parasite

Trypanosoma gambiense

Trypanosoma rhodesiense

Vectors

Glossina palpalis

Glossina morsitans

Primary reservoirs

Man-to-man transmission

Wild game animals

Illness

Chronic
  • Acute & rapidly progressive
  • Febrile paroxysms are more frequent
  • Myocarditis is more common & death may occur due to congestive heart failure

Duration of illness

Months to years

Less than 9 months

Lymphadenopathy (Winterbottom's sign)

Prominent

Minimal

CNS involvement

Late

Early

Parasitemia

Low

High

Investigations
  • Microscopy- Trypomastigote in blood
  • Rodent inoculation- Not useful
  • Microscopy- Trypomastigote in blood
  • Rodent inoculation-Diagnostic

Treatment
  • Pentamidine
  • Eflornithine
  • Melarsoprol
  • Suramin
  • Melarsoprol

questions.text: Which organism does the following life cycle correspond to?
questions.solution:
Correct answer (A) Giardia lamblia

The life cycle provided belongs to Giardia lamblia.

  • It includes 2 stages:
    • Trophozoite (or vegetative form)
    • Cysts (or cystic form).
  • Infective form: Mature cyst
  • Transmission: Feco oral route.
  • Habitat: Mucosa of duodenum and upper ileum.
  • Ingesting a minimum of 10 cysts can cause an infection in a person.
  • Within half an hour of ingestion, the cyst hatches out into two trophozoites, which multiply successively by binary fission and colonise the duodenum.
  • During unfavorable condition , encystment occurs and cyst are passed in stool and remain viable in soil and water for several weeks.
  • Life cycle: Host (only human) → Contaminated food and water (faeco-oral route) → Cyst (ingested form) → excystation occurs → Trophozoite.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Sample: Stool
    • Microscopy: Cyst and trophozoite are seen.
      • Trophozoite: 2 nuclei and four pairs of flagella with pear-shaped or tennis racket-shaped.
      • Cyst: 1-4 nuclei and no flagella.
    • String test: A capsule will have a string, and the capsule is swallowed, then the capsule goes to duodenum and dissolves, then the string is pulled back and, a microscopic examination is done.
    • Duodenal biopsy:
      • Giardia lamblia is a luminal organism
      • Organisms hanging in the lumen
      • Sickle shaped organism is seen.
      • Falling leaf motility is shown.
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole
    • Tinidazole (single dose of 2g)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a travel history to South America presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, mild chest pain, and palpitations. She reports a history of fever, malaise, and swelling around her right eye 11 months ago, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, her heart rate is irregular, and she has mild cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. Which treatment options are most appropriate for her at this stage?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with chronic Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. The history of fever and eyelid swelling points to a possible acute phase of the infection, while her current symptoms of fatigue, chest pain, palpitations, and cardiomegaly are typical complications of chronic Chagas disease.

Benznidazole is one of the two mainstays of treatment for Chagas disease. It is effective in both the acute and chronic phases, particularly when cardiac symptoms are present. Early treatment can help reduce the risk of progression to severe cardiac disease and complications. The recommended treatment duration is typically 60 days.

Nifurtimox (Option B) is another option for treating Chagas disease, but it is often associated with more significant side effects, including gastrointestinal issues and neurotoxicity. It is reserved for cases where benznidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated.

Supportive care and monitoring (Option C): While essential for managing symptoms and potential complications of Chagas disease (such as arrhythmias), this approach does not address the underlying infection.

Antiarrhythmic medications only (Option D) can help manage the arrhythmias associated with Chagas-related cardiomyopathy, E.g., beta-blockers and digoxin.

Supportive treatment such as pacemakers to manage arrhythmias and surgery for correction of megaesophagus and megacolon may be useful.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to diagnose T. cruzi?
questions.solution:
Yager’s LIT Medium (Liver Infusion Tryptose)- LIT medium is specifically designed to support the growth of Trypanosoma cruzi in laboratory settings, making it crucial for its diagnosis.

The diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, involves several methods.

  • Clinical Evaluation
    • Symptoms: Fever, fatigue, body aches, and chagoma (swelling at the infection site). Chronic symptoms affect the heart and digestive system.
    • History of travel or residence in endemic areas.
  • Serological Tests
    • ELISA: Detects antibodies against T. cruzi.
    • IHA: Measures antibodies in the blood.
    • Western Blot: Confirms positive serological results.
  • Microscopic Examination
    • Blood smears can detect the trypomastigote form, especially during the acute phase.
    • Giemsa or Wright’s stain enhances visibility.
  • Culture Methods
    • Yager’s LIT Medium: Cultures T. cruzi from blood or tissue samples, helpful in chronic cases.
  • Molecular Methods
    • PCR: Used for DNA detection.

 

Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (Option A): This medium is primarily used for cultivating fungi and some bacteria. It is not suitable for growing Trypanosoma cruzi.

 

Blood Agar (Option B): Blood agar is an enriched medium used for the cultivation of a wide variety of organisms, particularly fastidious bacteria. While it supports some protozoan growth, it is not specifically used for Trypanosoma cruzi diagnosis.


MacConkey Agar (Option D): This medium is selective for Gram-negative bacteria and differentiates lactose fermenters from non-fermenters. It is not suitable for protozoan cultures like Trypanosoma cruzi.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with persistent fatigue, chest pain, and difficulty breathing. He grew up in rural northern Argentina, where a childhood bug bite caused left eye swelling. Examination reveals leg swelling, an S3 gallop, and fatigue. IgG antibodies to Trypanosoma cruzi are detected by ELISA. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?


	Cardiac manifestations are seen in 30% with chronic form of disease.
	Benznidazole is considered a drug of choice for the chronic form of disease.
	Chronic form of disease has cardiac and gastrointestinal involvement.
	Peripheral blood microscopy can be used to diagnose chronic disease.
	The acute form of disease presents with a generalised rash.
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with cardiac involvement leading to fatigue, difficulty breathing, and Trypanosoma cruzi antibody detection in the peripheral blood is consistent with a chronic form of Chagas disease.

Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, transmitted by triatomine bugs.

 

Chagas’ disease occurs in four stages.

 

1. Early Stage Disease: It is characterised by cutaneous and ocular manifestations

  • Chagoma: a painful subcutaneous nodule at the site of deposition of bug’s faeces, commonly seen on the face.
  • Romana’s sign: It causes unilateral painless oedema of the eyelid and conjunctivitis.

2. Acute Chagas’ disease:

  • About 1% of patients, progress to acute-stage disease, characterised by fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy (Statement 5)

3. Indeterminate stage:

  • It is the asymptomatic phase; lasting for years to decades, before progressing into the symptomatic chronic stage

4. Chronic Chagas’ disease:

  • The parasite multiples in the muscles (cardiac and GIT) and nervous tissue, producing various types of manifestations.
  • Cardiac form: Occurs in 30% of the patients. The patient develops dilated cardiomyopathy, rhythm disturbances and thromboembolism.
  • Gastrointestinal form: Megaesophagus and megacolon.
  • Autoimmune hypothesis: T. cruzi antigens cross-react with mammalian antigens (molecular mimicry), producing autoantibodies that may be responsible for tissue injury seen in chronic Chagas’ disease

 

Treatment of Chagas disease

  • Therapy for Chagas’ disease is still unsatisfactory.
  • In acute disease, Benznidazole is the drug of choice in Latin America. Nifurtimox or allopurinol is given alternatively.
  • In chronic disease, these drugs lack efficacy and may cause many side effects. Supportive treatment, such as pacemakers to manage arrhythmias and surgery to correct megaesophagus and megacolon, may be useful (Statement 2).

 

In acute Chagas disease, the trypomastigotes are frequently found in peripheral blood, which can be detected by:

  • Wet mount preparation
  • Thick and thin smear examination.

Antibody detection: Chronic Chagas disease is diagnosed by detecting specific IgG antibodies using ELISA, Western blot and Chagas RIPA (radioimmunoprecipitation assay) (Statement 4).

questions.text: Which organism does this life cycle belong to?
questions.solution:
This is the life cycle of Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease.

The life cycle involves several stages and hosts:

  1. Triatomine Bug (Vector Stage): The cycle begins when a triatomine bug ("kissing bug") feeds on the blood of a human. During this feeding, the bug defecates, and the faeces containing the infective stage (metacyclic trypomastigotes) are introduced into the wound or mucous membranes.
  2. Trypomastigote Stage: Once inside the host, the metacyclic trypomastigotes invade host cells and transform into intracellular amastigotes. In this stage, they multiply by binary fission.
  3. Amastigote Stage: Inside the host cells (particularly in muscle and nerve tissues), the amastigotes reproduce and eventually transform back into trypomastigotes, which then burst out of the cells and enter the bloodstream.
  4. Re-infection in the Vector: When another triatomine bug bites an infected host, it ingests the trypomastigotes present in the blood. Inside the bug, the trypomastigotes transform back into epimastigotes and multiply in the insect’s gut. Eventually, they differentiate into metacyclic trypomastigotes, ready to infect another host.
  • In the Reduvid bug: Epimastigote and trypomastigote are seen.
  • In adults: Amastigote and trypomastigote are seen.


 

T. cruzi trypomastigotes in peripheral blood smear

questions.text: What is the drug of choice to treat Colpitis macularis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.solution:
Strawberry appearance of vaginal mucosa or cervix (Colpitis macularis) is observed in 2% of patients with Trichomoniasis. It is characterised by small punctate hemorrhagic spots on vaginal or cervical mucosa.

Metronidazole or tinidazole is the drug of choice for Trichomonas vaginalis.

  • Standard therapy: 2 g, single dose is usually effective.
  • Both sexual partners must be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection, especially asymptomatic males.
  • Resistance to metronidazole is rare but reported (2.5-10%). If the standard therapy fails (with 5-day therapy), consider repeating the treatment course.

 

Trichomoniasis can be prevented by:

  • Treatment of both sexual partners.
  • Safe sex practices like the use of condoms.
  • Avoidance of sex with an infected person.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with vaginal discharge and itching for 1 week. Examination findings are provided below. Which of the following culture media cannot be used to identify the causative organism in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct naswer (C) Novy Nicolle McNeal medium

The given scenario, featuring vaginal discharge, itching, and a strawberry cervix, is consistent with a diagnosis of Trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. This organism cannot be detected using Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle (NNN) medium, which is typically used for detecting Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania.

 

Diagnosis

  • Microscopy
    • Wet mount reveals,
      • The twitching (jerky or wobbling or rotatory) motility.
      • Pear shape with a single nucleus
      • 4 anterior flagella, 1 posterior flagella with an undulating membrane.
  • Permanent stain
    • Acridine orange, Papanicolaou and Giemsa stains can be used.
  • DFA (Direct fluorescent antibody)
    • More sensitive than wet mount
  • Culture
    • Most sensitive, gold standard investigation.
    • Following culture media can be used:
      • Lash cysteine hydrolysate serum
      • Diamond medium (Option A)
      • Trussell and Johnson medium (Option B)
      • Feinberg Whittington medium (Option D)
  • Serology
    • Tests like ELISA and Rapid immunochromatographic tests (lCTs) are also introduced.
  • Molecular method
    • DNA hybridisation, PCT, and nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) are also available now.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive male patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhoea. The histopathology of the duodenum shows trophozoites in the duodenal wall, as shown in the picture below. Which of the following features is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario and histopathological findings showing pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei and four pairs of flagella strongly suggest Giardia lamblia infection.
  • The small intestine morphology is usually normal, however, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.
  • Clinical features of giardiasis include:
  • Diarrhea
  • Steatorrhea
  • Dull epigastric pain.
  • Belching and flatulence.
  • Iron deficiency
  • Stool will have excess mucus and fat but no blood

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient is undergoing the test in the image below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given image?

choices.text: The Entero Test is used to diagnose giardiasis by obtaining duodenal specimens.
The String Test is used to diagnose amoebiasis by detecting trophozoites in the stool.
The Entero Test involves swallowing a coiled thread to diagnose echinococcosis by examining the liver.
The String Test is still widely used today due to its low cost and high diagnostic accuracy.

questions.solution:
• The given image depicts a String Test or Entero Test, which is used to diagnose giardiasis.
  • It is a useful method for obtaining duodenal specimens in giardiasis. (Option B & C ruled out)
  • In this test, the patient swallows a coiled thread inside a small, weighted gelatin capsule after attaching the free end of a thread to the cheek.
  • The capsule passes through the stomach to the duodenum. After 2 hours, the thread is withdrawn, placed in saline, and shaken.
  • The centrifuged deposit of saline is then examined for giardia.
  • Nowadays, the Entero test is not performed due to high cost. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and dehydration. A string test reveals a Giardia lamblia infection. After being treated with metronidazole, the patient does not fully respond, raising concerns about resistance. What would be the most appropriate next-line treatment?
questions.solution:
• For Giardia lamblia infection, Metronidazole is a drug of choice. However, some individuals may show resistance to metronidazole, leading to suboptimal treatment outcomes.
  • In such cases, an alternative treatment option is tinidazole, which is effective against giardia and offers the advantage of being administered as a single dose.
  • Treatment (DOC):
    • Metronidazole
    • Tinidazole (Single dose of 2g)

 

Paromomycin (option B) is used to treat intestinal protozoan infection but is not the next-line treatment after metronidazole resistance.

Doxycycline (option C) is an antibiotic commonly used for bacterial infections, but it is not a recommended treatment for giardia.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)(Option D): Antibiotic combination used for bacterial infection, not giardia.

questions.text: The microscopic examination of a wet mount preparation of stool from a patient with diarrhoea is shown below. Which organism is likely to exhibit this type of motility?
questions.solution:
The wet mount stool preparation displayed shows an organism exhibiting falling leaf-like motility, characteristic of Giardia lamblia (trophozoite is motile with a slow oscillation along its axis, resembling a falling leaf).

Types of motilities of microorganism:

Motility

Microorganism

Darting motility

Vibrio, Campylobacter

Swarming motility

Proteus

Tumbling motility

Listeria monocytogenes

Stately motility

Clostridia

Corkscrew motility

Treponema pallidum

Falling leaf motility

Giardia

Twitching motility

Eiknella corrodens

Jerky motility

Trichomonas vaginalis

Gliding motility

Mycoplasma

Lashing motility

Saprophytic spirochetes
